reviews.review_msg: Lectures hardly ever made it past the 1.5 hour point and were very vague and basically only a summary of the textbook. He seemed a little indecisive on what to teach. Better off just reading the textbook and not the lecture. Exams were difficult, but most questions were pulled from the textbook, so make sure to do the practice questions.

He seems like a good guy. He was not very clear with the grading as he changed his mind half way through the course. Exams were challenging and he did not give any part marks even when asked about a question. Quizzes were pass/fail which was good practice. Assignments didn't help. Lectures basically followed the textbook but had interesting studies

Dr. Woods makes the course really interesting and his lectures are enough to understand the material. He goes out of his way to help you with assignments and the material. His exams were based on the examples in his lectures and the assignments. Definitely recommend.

Dr. Woods is such an amazing professor. He genuinely cares about his students and if we're understanding the material. He was so helpful in office hours and can convey concepts very clearly during lecture. Also, he posts lecture slides ahead of time. Solid choice!!

Most understanding and reasonable prof I've ever had. He makes sure you understand concepts. Exams and Assignments were very reasonable and doable. Honestly would've loved to have him for STAT305 too. Bless his soul

clear explanations of concepts and preps the lecture slides beforehand so a plus. I suggest going to lectures to listen to better reinforce the material. the guest lectures are not tested on which is great. only two assignments and they are a great help to understand the material from lecture.

One of the best profs in HSCI. He is constantly updating his office hours . Hes willing to stay pass his office hours to help students and is extremely clear with what is expected on the exams. 2 assignments worth 20% but hes more then willing to help guide you through it. Currently takin this course and will take it again with him!!!

Scott makes an effort to help his students when in need, he also goes over assignments in class which is helpful so you can see what you may have made a mistake on. The course is not easy, but Scott tries to make content engaging and relevant which is helpful. Great professor in all. Assignments are fair, exams meant to be fair but can be hard

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS ONLINE!!! There is no support given to students who take HSCI 330 online. The TA was useless and the resources given did not help with assignments or exams. If you want to do well in this course take it in class.

One of the best profs at sfu. He tells you EXACTLY what you need to do to excel in the course. Two projects worth 20% each. Find a study group and do them an it's an easy A+ on both assignments. He gives you his speech notes as well so in case you miss class you know what he said. The examples he gives in class are REALLY helpful so go to class.

I loved the class and his lectures. Extremely clear and concise lectures, this guy knows his stuff. I found that joining study group helped for assignments and studying to bounce ideas off. Some of it is conceptual and you really need to have a handle on material for his tests. He is very available after class (finishes early) for questions.

great lecture slides and organized class, it would be good if you did the readings and chapter questions before attending class to understand what he is saying better. 1st assignment was fair but 2nd assignment was hard. Exams are quite fair but you need to know your stuff. Scott is really helpful and friendly and replies quite quickly to emails.

AMAZING PROF! I attended class maybe 3 times the whole semester and still ended with an A-. For midterm and final ONLY study the learning objectives and not all the extra readings assigned. Highly recommend Scott because he clearly states what will be tested on. Only 2 assignments, worth 20% each but both were fairly easy. Overall, easy A class!!!

Scott is a wonderful professor. He doesn't require students to attend the classes all the time. But if u go to his class, u will notice the lectures are short but clear. He gives a lot extra time for students to ask questions and he is patient. U can discuss the homework with other classmates. Through the homework, u can understand the content more

Dr. Venners is the definition of an excellent professor. He is VERY clear about what he expects of you (every lecture has learning objectives - know those and you will be fine for the tests!). The class is well organized on WebCT. He is really passionate about Epi, makes it very relevant and wants students to succeed. Highly recommended!

Scott can teach. It's unfortunate that he's a victim of FHS incompetence (as were students this semester). Last semester he was too easy; this semester too hard. Lousy textbook! Shame, because it's an interesting subject.
She is the most useless professor to walk the halls of SFU. Enough said.

Everything in this class was self-taught - A LOT OF INFO. Her lecture slides are very repetitive and the colours make them hard to read. One assignment worth 20% and midterm and final both worth 30%. Reading the text and doing the practice qs are necessary for passing. Not available for extra help and will not answer ANY questions during exams.

Dr. Samji is an excellent professor who is thoroughly knowledgeable about epidemiology. Her tests are fair and based off of the textbook. Would recommend familiarizing oneself with end of chapter questions.  The class average was a B so I wouldn't say it was too hard of a class.

hands done one of the best profs at SFU ! she makes understanding stats epidemiology a breeze. Her midterm was quite lengthy but if you know her powerpoint slides in and out and do the readings and qs in the readings you're good to go ! she doesn't try to trick you as some of the q's were pulled out from the text. scales heavily for exams !

Most people give Meghan a poor rating because they get shredded on her exams. If you're not specific, you won't get the marks. The course material is easy, anyone with basic English and math has the potential to get an A in this course. If you mess up on math calculations or don't describe the math in words on testsassignments, good bye grades!
lectures are really clear, and Dr Winters is really helpful when you need clarifications . Overall, I enjoyed this class

The class itself is not that difficult, but Meghan can be unclear sometimes.  When students ask questions she acts really condescending and arrogant and thats really frustrating! Theres a male prof that teaches this class too, take it with him! As she uses all his notes anyways..

I found meghan to be really rude and unfriendly. She tells the class that shes available for extra help, but shes actually a little scary. the class itself isnt too bad, as the notes used by another prof are very informative
not friendly at all.

Class itself was alright, but she is not a good teacher. She teaches the subject well, but she makes her students feel inferior. She is a very condescending person which is why I would not recommend her. If you are interested in Stats the subject is not too difficult, but she really makes you feel stupid for asking a question. UNCOOL!

She knows what she's talking about but isn't very clear in explaining concepts. A lot of review in the textbook is needed outside class. Also, she was not very helpful in office hours. Although I do not have personal experience with this, I feel it might be difficult to understand her especially if you are ESL.

Overall, a relatively simple class. 1 midterm, 1 final, non-cumulative. However, there are 2 assignments and they are worth 20% each which is a bit much. She's a decent prof and will take the time to explain things. I recommend her class, she's interesting.

Knowledgeable teacher who is very passionate about his courses. His lecs are not dry since he tends to mix in humor. You will def do well in the course if you READ the text and use his notes. I believe a lot of the bad reviews are from students who rely too heavily on the assumption that he is an easy teacher and therefore do not put in any effort!

I enjoyed having Dr. Hayashi as a prof. Her lectures were organized, she gave practice questions and lectures to walk you through examples that came in handy for assignments and exams. Some assignment and exam questions did not necessarily have a right/wrong answer as long as you gave a meaningful explanation. The TA's were also very helpful.

Kanna is a kind professor. Her accent and way of teaching made it slightly hard for me to learn from her personally. The textbook is good at explaining stuff and I recommend it. I didn't watch her lectures and got 85% or more on everything leading up to the Final. The take-home final was hard but we had 4 days for it so can't really complain there.

She is the perfect prof for online courses. You don't need to watch/read the lectures or any of her provided course material. All you need to do is read the textbook pages she assigns which take like 45 mins/week and you are good. This is what I did along with some others and I'm pretty sure we're gonna get As. The final was a take-home exam too.

Do not take this course with Kanna. Her final exam is 30% and is ridiculously hard, nothing like her assignments, midterm or quizzes. Her quizzes were just for completion and she gives a practice midterm. However, the marking on her exam was brutal.

Honestly, it's not Dr. Hayashi's fault - epidemiology is boring. That being said, sometimes she doesn't communicate topics very well, and you'd best show up to her lectures simply because her lecture slides don't always give the full picture. Aside from this, though, she's very caring and passionate about her work. Glad I got to learn epi from her.

I'm glad I took this class with her simply because she went into such depth for her explanations. She reviews the previous weeks materials and tries to make it as understandable as possible. Though because of this lectures do become very long and dry. 2 assignments corresponding to the material we've learnt 20% each + a midterm and final 30% each.

While the material in the class can be difficult, especially because Kanna goes into very detailed explanations, if you attend class you will do fine. She outlines exactly what you need to do each week in order to stay up to date, if you follow these instructions and ask questions when you do not understand you will do fine.
